pull.title: tx pool: Use class methods to hide raw map iterator impl details
pull.body:
ATMP et al would often use map iterator implementation details such as `end()` or `find()`, which is acceptable in current code.

However, this not only makes it impossible to turn the maps into private members in the future but also makes it harder to replace the maps with different data structures.

This is required for and split off of #13804

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->Note to reviewers: This pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #13804 (Transaction Pool Layer by MarcoFalke)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

issue.title: tx pool: Avoid passing redundant hash into addUnchecked (scripted-diff)
issue.body:
Several years ago the transaction hash was not cached. For optimization the hash was instead passed into `addUnchecked` to avoid re-calculating it. See f77654a0e9424f13cad04f82c014abd78fbb5e38

Passing in the hash is now redundant and the argument can safely be removed.

issue.title: WIP: Transaction Pool Layer
issue.body:
This implements a layer around an immutable tx pool. The layer can be seen as a temporary throw-away shell that provides the same interface as `CTxMemPool`. Its primary purpose right now is to be passed into ATMP while testing acceptance of several (potentially depending) transaction and then to be discarded.

One use case could be to determine if smart contracts that are set up with multiple txs would be accepted by current consensus and policy rules.

In the future it could be extended to support recursive wrapping of layers or a way to commit changes that happened in the layer to the underlying pool or layer. Furthermore, it could be extended to be revivable after changes to the underlying layer happened. (As opposed to be single-use)

comments.body: Nit: the name sounds like it's a getter + setter operator. Maybe call it `GetIterSet`?
Nit: I think the convention is to not prefix variables with types anymore and to use `snake_case`.
It is used in a couple of places further down, so I will keep the name for now.
Weird, it looked like you renamed `itConflicting` to `ptxConflicting`, but `ptxConflicting` existed already. My bad.
Renamed to `GetIterSet` according to your feedback
as the result is only ever used to iterate over, and the input is already unique, does this need to return a set? I guess a std::list would be a better match
OK I guess I'm wrong, there might be duplicate parents
